facts.text: Six writ petitions filed under Article 32 of the Constitution challenging the validity of the Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: These six writ petitions which have been filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution, seek to challenge the validity of the Constitution  17th Amendment  Act, 1964.

facts.text: Petitioners are affected by one or more Acts added to the Ninth Schedule by the 17th Amendment Act.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioners are affected by one or the other of the Acts added to the 9th Schedule by the impugned Act, and their companytention is that the impugned Act being companystitutionally invalid

facts.text: Interveners similarly affected by other Acts added to Ninth Schedule and join petitioners in contending invalidity.

anchor.surface_text: Some other parties who are similarly affected by other Acts added to the 9th Schedule by the impugned Act, have intervened at the hearing of these writ petit ions

facts.text: 17th Amendment Act consists of three sections: short title, adds proviso to cl.(1) Art.31A, substitutes sub-cl.(a) cl.2 Art.31A, amends 9th Schedule adding 44 entries.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned Act companysists of three sections. The first section gives its short title. Section 2 i  adds a proviso to cl.  1  of Art. 31A after the existing proviso.

facts.text: New proviso to Art.31A(1): State cannot acquire land under personal cultivation within ceiling limit unless compensation not less than market value.

anchor.surface_text: Provided further that where any law makes any provision for the acquisition by the State of any estate and where any land companyprised therein is held by a person under his personal cultivation

facts.text: Substitution of sub-cl.(a) cl.2 Art.31A expands definition of 'estate' to include jagir, inam, muafi, janmam rights, ryotwari land, agricultural land etc.

anchor.surface_text: Section 2  ii  substitutes the following sub- clause for sub-cl.  a  of cl.  2  of Art. 31A-  a  the expression estate shall, in relation to any local area

facts.text: Section 3 of 17th Amendment adds 44 entries to Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 amends the 9th Schedule by adding 44 entries to it.

facts.text: Articles 31A and 31B added by Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951 with retrospective effect.

anchor.surface_text: Articles 31A and 3 1 B were added to the Constitution with retrospective effect by S. 4 of the Constitution  First Amendment  Act, 1951.

facts.text: Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955 amended Art.31A and added one more Act to Ninth Schedule.

anchor.surface_text: The second step in the same direction was taken by Parlia- ment in 1955 by amending Art. 31A by the Constitution  Fourth Amendment  Act, 1955.

facts.text: Kerala Agrarian Relations Act, IV of 1961 struck down by Supreme Court on December 5, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: In Karimbil Kunhikoman v. State of Kerala 1 , the validity of the Kerala Agrarian Relations Act  IV, of 1961  was challenged... This decision was pronounced on December 5, 1961.

facts.text: Madras Land Reforms (Fixation of Ceiling on Land) Act, No.58 of 1961 declared invalid by Supreme Court on March 9, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: In A. P. Krishnaswami Naidu, etc. v. The State of Madras  2 the companystitutionality of the Madras Land Reforms  Fixation of Ceiling on Land  Act  No. 58 of 1961 ... pronounced on March 9, 1964

facts.text: Rajasthan Tenancy Act III of 1955 declared invalid.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Rajasthan Tenancy Act HI of 1955 and the Maharashtra Agricultural Lands  Ceiling and Holdings  Act 27 of 1961 have been similarly declared invalid

facts.text: Maharashtra Agricultural Lands (Ceiling on Holdings) Act 27 of 1961 declared invalid.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Rajasthan Tenancy Act HI of 1955 and the Maharashtra Agricultural Lands  Ceiling and Holdings  Act 27 of 1961 have been similarly declared invalid

facts.text: High Court of Patna held Bihar land legislation unconstitutional in Kameshwar v. State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Patna held that the relevant Bihar legislation was unconstitutional, whilst the High Courts at Allahabad and Nagpur upheld the validity

facts.text: Court holds 17th Amendment valid, does not attract proviso to Art.368.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore the main companytention raised by the petitioners and the interveners against the validity of the impugned Act must be rejected.

facts.text: Pith and substance of 17th Amendment is to amend fundamental rights to facilitate agrarian reform.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, if the pith and substance test is applied to the amendment made by the impugned Act, it would be clear that Parliament is seeking to amend fundamental rights solely with the object of removing any possible obstacle

facts.text: Sri Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India upheld First Amendment Act.

anchor.surface_text: The question about the validity of the Constitution  First Amendment  Act has been companysidered by this Court in Sri Sankari Prasad Singh Deo v. Union of India and State of Bihar 1

facts.text: Court declines to reconsider Sankari Prasad decision.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the plea made by the petitioners for reconsidering Sankari Prasads case is wholly unjustified and must be rejected.

facts.text: Art.13(2) does not apply to constitutional amendments under Art.368.

anchor.surface_text: the word law used in Art. 13 must be taken to mean rules or regulations made in exercise of ordinary legislative power and number amendments to the Constitution made in exercise of companystituent power

facts.text: Writ petitions dismissed, no order as to costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the impugned Act is companystitutionality valid. The petitions, accordingly, fail and are dismissed. There will be numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by P.B. Gajendragadkar C.J. for himself, Wanchoo, Raghubar Dayal JJ.; separate judgments by Hidayatullah and Mudholkar JJ.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of P. B. GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J., K. , N. WANCHOO and RAGHUBAR DAYAL JJ. was delivered by GAJENDRAGADKAR C.J. HIDAYATULLAH and J. R. MUDHOLKAR JJ. delivered separate judgments.

facts.text: Originally 19 Acts in Ninth Schedule after First Amendment; 20 after Fourth Amendment.

anchor.surface_text: At this time, 19 Acts were listed in Schedule 9... One more Act was added to this list by the Amendment Act of 1955, so that as a result of the second amendment, the Schedule companytained 20 Acts

facts.text: Agrarian reform legislation in Bihar, UP, MP challenged in High Courts leading to First Amendment.

issues.text: what the true scope and effect of Art. 368 is

anchor.surface_text: In dealing with the question about the validity of the impugned Act, it is necessary to consider the scope and effect of the provisions contained in Art. 368 of the Constitution, because a large part of the controversy in the present writ petitions turns upon the decision of the question as to what the true scope and effect of Art. 368 is.

issues.text: what would be the requirement about making an amendment in a constitutional provision contained in Part III, if as a result of the said amendment, the powers conferred on the High Courts under Art. 226 are likely to be affected ?

anchor.surface_text: The question which calls for our decision is what would be the requirement about making an amendment in a constitutional provision contained in Part III, if as a result of the said amendment, the powers conferred on the High Courts under Art. 226 are likely to be affected ?

holdings.text: The impugned Act (Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964) is constitutionally valid and does not attract the proviso to Article 368.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, if the pith and substance test is applied to the amendment made by the impugned Act, it would be clear that Parliament is seeking to amend fundamental rights solely with the object of removing any possible obstacle... Therefore the main contention raised by the petitioners and the interveners against the validity of the impugned Act must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance of amendment is to amend fundamental rights for agrarian reform; indirect and insignificant effect on Art.226 powers; harmonious construction of Art.368.

holdings.text: In the result, we hold that the impugned Act is constitutionally valid. The petitions, accordingly, fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, we hold that the impugned Act is constitutionally valid. The petitions, accordingly, fail and are dismissed. There will be no order as to costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects all petitioner contentions after examining scope of Art.368, proviso applicability, Art.13, and precedent.

holdings.text: The word 'law' in Article 13(2) does not include constitutional amendments made under Article 368.

anchor.surface_text: the word law used in Art. 13 must be taken to mean rules or regulations made in exercise of ordinary legislative power and not amendments to the Constitution made in exercise of constituent power

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of Art.13 and 368; 'law' refers to ordinary legislative power, not constituent power; follows Sankari Prasad.

holdings.text: The plea made by the petitioners for reconsidering Sankari Prasad's case is wholly unjustified and must be rejected.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the plea made by the petitioners for reconsidering Sankari Prasads case is wholly unjustified and must be rejected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Stare decisis applies absent compelling reasons; decision followed extensively; reopening would invalidate prior amendments.

holdings.text: Article 368 empowers Parliament to amend all provisions of the Constitution, including those in Part III.

anchor.surface_text: the expression amendment of the Constitution plainly and unambiguously means amendment of all the provisions of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation; substantive part applies broadly; proviso carves out exceptions; no exclusion of fundamental rights.

holdings.text: The power to amend under Article 368 includes power to abridge or take away fundamental rights in Part III.

anchor.surface_text: the amendment of a law may in a proper case include the deletion of any one or more of the provisions of the law and substitution in their place of new provisions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide amplitude of 'amend'; dictionary meaning inappropriate; follows Sankari Prasad; necessary for socio-economic progress.

holdings.text: The impugned Act does not constitute legislation in respect of land under Entry 18 List II; it validates state land legislations.

anchor.surface_text: What the impugned Act purports to do is not to make any land legislation but to protect and validate the legislative measures in respect of agrarian reforms passed by the different State Legislatures

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance test: constitutional amendment, not land law; Parliament exercises constituent power.

holdings.text: The impugned Act validly sets aside prior court decisions declaring certain Acts invalid by adding them to Ninth Schedule retrospectively.

anchor.surface_text: legislative power to make laws in respect of areas entrusted to the legislative jurisdiction of different legislative bodies, can be exercised both prospectively and retrospectively.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Constituent/legislative power operates retrospectively; common practice to validate notwithstanding judgments.

holdings.text: There is no force in the contention that the 17th Amendment required the special procedure laid down in the proviso to Art.368.

anchor.surface_text: I agree, with him that there is no force in the contention that the 17th Amendment required for its valid enactment the special procedure, laid down in the proviso to Art., 368.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art.226 unchanged; enlarges 'estate' in 31A and protects Acts via 31B/Ninth Schedule; follows Sankari Prasad on similar point.

holdings.text: Parliament may consider including provisions of Part III in the proviso to Art.368 to avoid anomalies.

anchor.surface_text: Before we part with this matter, we would like to observe that Parliament may consider whether it would not be expedient and reasonable to include the provisions of Part III in the proviso to Art. 368.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Observation on potential anomaly between Art.226 and 32; matter for Parliament.
